EVERIE Woman in her Humor.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Accutus Boss Citizens wife Cicero Boy Flavia/Prologue Graccus Host Hostess Cornutus Caesar Lentulus Flaminius Terentia Prentice Philantus Getica Scillicet Seruulus Tulley Masker/Song Drawer Fryer Combined speech Constable Porter 1 Porter 2

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.p: Gentles of both sexes, and all sorts, I am sent to bid ye welcome, I am but instead of a Prologue: for a she prologue is as rare as an Usurers Alms: non reperitur in vsu, and the rather I come woman, because men are apt to take kindly any kind thing at a woman's hand; and we poor souls are but too kind, if we be kindly entreated, marry otherwise, there I make my Aposiopesis: the Author hath indeed made me an honest merry wench, one of his humorists, yet I am so much beholding to him, I cannot get me a husband in his play that is worth the having, unless I be better half of the suitor myself: and having imposed this audacity on me, he sends me hither first for exercise I come among ye all: these are the Contents, that you would hear with patience, judge with lenity, and correct with smiles, for the which our endeavours shall show itself like a tall fellow in action: if we shall join hands, a bargain. As a lowly earnest, I give this courtesy before, And in conceit I give ye twenty more.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Nay, but Accutus, prithee what misshapen vizard of Melancholy hast thou masked thyself in? thou lookest as thou wert changing thy religion: what? is there a breach in thy Faith? come, declare, and let me set thy wits on work, to amend it.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Ha ha ha!

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Pretty: a man is well advised to offer good counsel, and be laughed at for his labour: we shall shortly have no Counsellors but Physicians, I spend my breath to thee, and thou answerest me some half an hour after in a sembreue, or like to a Sexton with a Sobeit or Amen.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: Condemn my Stars then.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: I should wrong am then, as thou dost with a false indictment, I know it took not, being at thy birth, thou hast been merry, thou hast sounded hoops, swallowed whiffs, walked late, worn favours, seen whoresons: thou canst feel and understand, come, thou hast been a sinner: unload, discharge, untune, confess, is venus dominatrix? art not in love?

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Yes, I love God and my neighbours.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Then either for Gods sake or thy Neighbours, or both, be smooth, and participate, is it not some underlayer, some she Camel that will bear as much of her belly, as three beasts on their backs? some Lantern maker, I will hold thy head: come, up with it.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Prithee I hate none, but heaven hate me if I be in love with any.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Off with these clogs, then break prison, and get out of this melancholy Gaol, hark how the general noise doth welcome from the Parthian wars, each spirit is jocund, fraught with glee, then wrong not thine with this dull meditation.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: O! how do they then wrong my meditation? my thoughts are with themselves at a counsel, till with noise and thou with continual talk, hast driven them to a nonplus.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Then make me of thy counsel, and take my advice, for I will take no deny all, I will not leave thee till the next new Almanacs be out of date: let him threaten the sharpest weather he can, in Saint Swithin week, or it snow on our Ladies face, I will not budge, I will be thy mid-wife till thou beest delivered of this passion.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Partake then, and give me the belief: thinkst thou or knowest thou any of this opinion, that, that moving marish element, that swells and swags as it please the moon, to be in bigness equal to that solid lump that brings us up?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I was sure thou wert beyond the Antipodes: faith I am of that faith I was brought up in, I have heard my Father say, and I am sure his Records came from his Father, that the Land and Sea are in nature thus much alike; the one grows by the Sun, the other by the Moon, both by Gods blessing; and the Sea rather the greater, and so think I.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Good: there we have a farther scope, and hold the sea, can (as a looking glass) answer with a mere smile any moving shape upon the earth.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Nay, that is most certain, I have heard of Seahorses, Sea-calves, and Sea monsters.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: O, they are monstrous mad, merry wenches, and they are monsters Graccus, they call them Sea-maids or Mermaids singing sweetly, but none dares trust them, and are very like our Land wenches, devouring Serpents from the middle downward.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Thou hast even given me satisfaction: but hast thou this by proof?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Not by my travels (so God help me) marry I will bring ye forty Sailors will swear they have seen them.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: In truth!

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: In truth or otherwise.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p:
Faith they are not unlike our land monsters, else why should this Maximilian Lord, for whom these shoots and noises befits thus, forsake his honours, to sing a Lullaby?
These seeming Saints, alluring evils, That make earth Erebus, and mortals devils.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Come, thou art Seasick, and will not be well at ease till thou hast taken a vomit, up with it.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p:
Why i'faith I must, I cannot soothe the world With velvet words, and oily flatteries, And kiss the sweaty seat of magnitude, To purchase smiles, or a dead man's office, I cannot hold to see a rib of man A move of itself, command the whole Baffle, and bend to muliebrity Of female scandals; observe, do but observe, Here one walks overgrown in weeds of pride, The earth wants shape, to apply a simile, A body prisoned up with walls of wire, With bones of whales, somewhat hat allied to fish But from the waist declining, more loose doth hang, Than her wanton dangling lascivious lock that is whirled and blown with every lustful breath. Her neck in chains, all naked lies her breast, Her body lighter than the feathered crest. Another pouts and scowls, and hangs the lip, Even as the bankrupt credit of her husband, Cannot equal her with honours livery, What doth she care, if for to deck her brave,
He is carried from a Gatehouse to his grave. Another in a railing pulpit key, Draws through her nose the accent of her voice, And in the presence of her good man Goat, Cries fie, now fie upon these wicked men.
That use such beastly and inhumane talk: When being in private, all her studies warn, To make him enter into Capricorn. Another as she goes, treads a Canary pace, Jets it so fine, and minces so demure, As mistress Bride upon her marriage day: Her heels are Cork, her body Atlas, Her Beauty bought, her soul an Atomus. Another with a spleen devoured face, Her eyes as hollow as Anatomy: Her tongue more venom than a Serpents sting, Which when it wags within her chap fallen jaws, Is noise more horrid than a cry of hounds With open mouths, pursuing of their game, Wants she but rich attire or costly diet, With her the Devil can never live in quiet. Yet these are weaker vessels, heaven doth know, Lay on them ought but ease, you do them wrong: They are as weak as water, and indeed as strong, And then like mighty ships, when pellets sink,
To them lay more men, she will never shrink.

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: Mistress, that face wants a fresh Gloss.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Prithee dip it in well Boss.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Pigmaleon, Pigmaleon, I conjure thee appear, To work, to work, make more Marble Ingles, Nature, thou art a fool, Art is above thee: Belzebub, paint thy face, there is some will love thee.

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: Rare, Mistress, Here is a cheek like a Chameleon or a blazing Star: you shall hear me blaze it, here is two saucers sanguine in a sable field, pomegranate, a pure pendant, Ready to drop out of the stable, a pin and web argent in hair de Roy.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: And a fools head in the Crest.

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: In the Crest? O sweet Vermilion mistress! it is pity the Vermilion Worms should eat thee, I will set it with precious stones if ye will.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Enough sweet Boss, throw a little water to spurt his face and let us away.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Hold up, so sir now away: O Mistress your scantling, most sweet mistress most derry dent star.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Then most rident stars fair fall ye.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Nay sure it is the Moon herself, for there is her man and her Dog before.

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: Aye sir, but the man is not in the moon, and my bush is before me, ergo not at my back, et ergo, not moon sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: What is your will sir?

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: That you would leave us.

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: Leave you 'swounds sir, we scorn their companies, come, they are full, do not open to them, we have no Conies to catch.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Away, keep no distance, even both together, For wit, ye may be Coached together. What sleek browed Saint can see this Idiotism, The shape and workmanship of omnipotency, To be so blind with drugs of beastliness, And will not bend the brow, and bite the lip, Trouble his quiet soul, with venom spleen, And fear lest the all overseer, Can without vengeance, see these ignominies.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Why therefore are they beloved like Sergeants, and entertained like Beggars, thinkst thou but any honourable Gate but will be shut against these Butterflies?

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: O Graecus ! thou beguilest opinion, The Gates of great men stand more wide To entertain a fool, than Cresus arms, To hug his Golden God: and faster bard Against necessity, than Dives entrance At Olympus gate.

div2.stage: Enter Sernulas, Scillicet, Philantus and Boy.

sp.speaker: Sernu.
sp.p: Fa, la, sol, la sol: Boy a Glass;

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It is but one and all sir.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Angels protect us, what have we here?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ye have a good memory Sir, for they are five minutes ere windfall of your Glass.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, be credible, it is balanced to be a superlative politic custom in these hours to dwell in shallow accoutrements, as a defence for the ability of his purse, from the infringed Oath of some impudent face, that will borrow a gentleman's revenues, if he be vestally adorned: I will tell you sir, by this bright Horrison ---

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: A word I pray ye sir ere ye go any further: Boy my Tables?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Your Tables are ready Sir, and all the men ye keep which is indeed half a Boy, Scillicet, Videlicet.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I pray ye let me request that oath of you.

sp.speaker: Sern.
sp.p: A graceful enquiry, and well observed: Sir my company shall make ye copious of novelties let your Tables befriend your memory: write, by this bright Horizon.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Here is none but only I, sing: Boy, how likest thou my head of hair?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Your Glass may flatter ye, but truly I will not, your head is not a hair better than it should be.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Is there any scarcity of hair Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Somewhat thin, and yet there is more hair than wit.

sp.speaker: Phy:
sp.p: How Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then wit of man can number sir, take it in the right sense I pray ye.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Most ingenious!

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: O muffle, muffle good Graccus, do not taint thy sense, With sight of these infectious animals, Lest reason in thee have the upper hand To govern sense, to see and shun the sight: Here is new discovered sins, past all the rest, Men strive by practise how to swear the best.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I have quoted it sir, by this bright Whore, Whore son, pronounce ye sir.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Horizon the Widows mite Sir?

sp.speaker: Sern.
sp.p: Not for the Sultans crown sir.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Indeed ye shall, by this bright horizon ye shall, believe me if I swear, I think myself beholding, for I know it to be no common oath.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Were it common, it past not these doors: Sir, I shift my oaths as I wash my hands, twice in the artificial day, for in dialoguising, it is to be observed, your sentences must ironically, metaphorically, and altogether figuratively mixed with your morning oaths.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Faith it is very true.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: That he neither knows what he says, nor thou understandest.

sp.speaker: Seru:
sp.p: As for example, by this illuminate welkin.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: O excellent! it shall down too.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p:
There is another Ducat, he utters his oaths apace.
Sure this Villain has no soul, and for gold He will damn his body too, He is at peace with hell, And brings his Merchandise from thence to sell.

sp.speaker: Boy.
Phy.
sp.p: Boy, sleep wayward thoughts.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Is it not now most amiable and fair?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes sir God be praised.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: What meanest thou Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The weather sir.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I mean my hair and face Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: It were amiable if it would not alter.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Wherefore, I often repair it.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Methinks that should wear it the sooner.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Not so Boy, for to trim the Hair well, is a rare quality: to be rare lie qualified is to be wise, apply Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That you are wise in trimming your hair Master?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Right, to be wise is to be rare, for it is rare to see a wise man.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: True Master: but if you will see a fool look in your Glass master.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Go to, I must correct you Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You can correct no more than is your own, I am but half yours to command, if you steal away any part that is not your own, you are so far in danger as the striking of an other man's servant.

sp.speaker: Phy:
sp.p: By this illuminate welkin most sincere and singular, as a small remembrance.

sp.speaker: Seru,
sp.p: Not for to win the fair Angelica.

sp.speaker: Scillicet:
sp.p: By this illuminate Welkin ye shall now.

sp.speaker: Seru:
sp.p: Sir, I do not bestow it for that I think you have need of it, for if you had, by this bright Horizon I would not give it, for I know it is no credit to give to the poor, by this illuminate welkin, I have (since I took upon me this fleshy desire of a Gentleman) thrown out of a window for a hunt is up, when I had as lief have heard the grinding of a Mustard Mill, for those are things are here today and gone tomorrow: this will stick by a man, and do him credit where ever he goes.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p:
Aye, when the fool is clad in clay,
It will stick sore unto thy soul for aye.

sp.speaker: Phy:
sp.p: Seignior Scillicet, I assure you I have discovered the most quaint and new found device for the encounter of the Ladies at the interview, it is in pricksong.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: that is excellent and rare.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Aye, for prick-song to Ladies is most pleasant and delightful, as thus for your conge, All hail to my beloved: then for your departure, sad despair doth drive me hence: for all must be to effect.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Nay, prithee raise no quarrels.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: I can hold no longer, hear you sir, are not you a fool? and you an Ass? and you a knave?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: 'swounds an Ass?

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: A Fool?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: A Knave without respect?

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Aye, for an Ass can bear, a Fool abide, and a Knave deserve:

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Help, help!

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Prithee let us away.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Fools oftentimes brings wise men to trouble, Farewell, another time I will pay ye double.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Bring your Clubs out of doors, there go in my fine hostess, I will talk to the proudest: what knaves are in the street, my door is my door, my house is my castle, go in dame Helena, let thine host alone with this: he that knocks at my hobby, while I have Ale in my house, shall pay for a Surgeon: the honest shall come in, the knaves shall go by: bring Clubs I say.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Nay sir, the hear is past, they that did it have took them to their heels, for indeed here are of us ---

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Away with your Clubs then, welcome my brave Bullies, my Guests shall take no wrong, but welcome my Bullies.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Indeed sir I am a man of few words, I have put up a little bloodshed, marry I hope it shall be no stain to my manhood, if I keep it out of my clothes.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
He shall pay for the bloodshed, my guests shall take no wrong: mine Host will spend his Cruz as frank
as an Emperor: welcome my brave bullies.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, be pacifical, the fellow was possessed with some critique frenzy, and we impute it to his madness.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Mad! by Gods 'slid if he were as mad as a weaver, I can hardly put it up: for my blow: I care not so much, but he called me fool: 'slid if I live till I die, the one of us shall prove it.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: Some profane Villain, I will warrant him.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Do you think I may not have an action against him?

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: There is so many swaggerers, but alas, how fell ye out?

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: By the welkin I gave him not a foul word: first he calls me fool, then he makes a full blow at my body, and if by good chance I had not warded it with my head, he might have spoiled me.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: There, there, my fine fill-pots: give the word as you pass: anon anon sir, anon: here and there in the twinkling look well to the bar, there again my little Mercuries, froth them up to the brim, and fill as it is needful: if their pates be full of Wine, let your Pattles be three quarters, trip and go, here and there: now any brave Lad wash thy wounds with good Wine: bid am welcome my little Sybil: put sugar in his hole there, I must in to my guests, sleep soundly till morning: Canary is a Jewel, and a Fig for Browne bastard.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: Gentlemen, ye are welcome, though my husband be a little talkative, yet truly he is an unreasonable honest man, ye shall find his words and his sayings all one.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: I think no less, yet I would desire to enter as time and place shall serve.

sp.speaker: Hostess:
sp.p: I will lead the way forsooth.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p:
Nay pray ye Hostess a word, I say little, but I am sure I have sustained the most wrong: by this light, I
had rather he had broke my head in three places, I pray you lend me a brush, he has put my hat quite out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: That shall ye sir, a brush there ho!

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: Salve, sis saluus, I pray ye which of you five is the Hostess of the house?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: That is easily discerned, for four wear breeches.

sp.speaker: Boss:
sp.p: Never the sooner for that my diminutive youth, for women nowadays wear breeches as well as men, marry the difference lies in the bauble.
Well sir, to open the truth I am the Hostess.
The fruit is known by the Tree at the first view, as the Author writes learnedly, come, basilus manus.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: This kissing becomes a Gentleman, I will use it sure

sp.speaker: Boss:
sp.p: Secondly, Mistress Hostess, I would know what lodging ye have for my Lady and her train.

sp.speaker: Hostess:
sp.p: What will serve your turn sir?

I will call myself to account and specify thus: my Lady and her Dog that is two visible: then there is the Dog and my Lady, that is four invisible: then there is my Ladies dog and I quoth the dog, that is six: then there is sequence of three, viz. the Dog and I and my Lady: then there is a pair of Knaves, viz the Dog and myself, and my Lady turned up: viz my Lady sequence of three: a pair of knaves, and my Lady turned up to play upon, we can have no less than five beds.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: Truly you must lie close together, (the Servants I mean) for I am so thrust with Guest I can hardly spare so many.
Faith we will lie together as close as we can: there is my Lady and her dog lie altogether, and I at the beds feet, and there is all our family of Love.

sp.speaker: Hostess:
sp.p: How far is your mistress behind?

The truth is, the fatal sisters have cut the thread of her cork shoe, and she is stepped aside into a Cobblers shop to take a true stitch, whether I mean to send myself as
a Court of Guard to conduct her: but see, O, inconstant fortune I see where she comes solus.

sp.speaker: Gent,
sp.p: Boss, you serve me well to let me wait upon myself.

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: Of two evils the least is to be chosen, I had a care of your puppy being less than yourself.

sp.speaker: Scil,
sp.p: Gentlewoman you have an excellent Ch: I have an appetite as a man would say.

sp.speaker: Gent,
sp.p: What is your will sir?

sp.speaker: Scil,
sp.p: Truth will to light, and the truth is, I have an appetite to kiss you.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: This point would become a Gentleman sure, I pray who trimmed it so?

sp.speaker: Gent,
sp.p: My man forsooth.

sp.speaker: Phy,
sp.p: Sir, I desire your acquaintance, it is excellent rare.

sp.speaker: Gent;
sp.p: You would have said so, had you seen it an hour since.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here is game for me, I hunt for fools, and have sprung a cony.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p:
Gentles, please you draw near? lead the way
into the chambers.

sp.speaker: Boss;
sp.p: Boss is the name of a thing may be seen, felt, heard, or understood, and the nominative case goes before, my Mistress the Verb, my mistress requires an accusative case to follow, as vsus feminae proptus facit.

sp.speaker: Hostess;
sp.p: O fie upon it, who would be an hostess, and could do otherwise? Lady, as the most lascivious life, conges and kisses, the attire, the hood, the rebato, the loose bodied Gown, the pin in the hair, and every day change, when an Hostess must come and go at every man's pleasure: and what is a Lady more than another body? we have legs and hands, rolling eyes, hanging lips, sleek brows, and cherry cheeks, and other things as Ladies have, but the fashion carries it away.

sp.speaker: Host;
sp.p: There, there my little Lackey boys, again, again, my fine fill-pots, where is my fine Hostess? come, come my little dido, set your corks on a creaking, my knaves are unthrifty, dance not your canaries, here, up and down, look about to my Guests I say.

sp.speaker: Hostess:
sp.p: Aye, I have much joy, an Hostess!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What, abides my Penenelope? here stand thy Vlisses, I will tarry with thee still, thou shalt want for no cost, I will buy thee a brave whistle, look about to my Guests I say.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p:
Aye, Hostesses will be known shortly as their
Signs, still in one weather-beaten suite, as though none wear hoods but Monks and Ladies: and feathers, but fore-horses, and Waiting Gentlewomen: or chains but prisoners and Courtiers: no Periwigs but Players and Pictures, but the weakest must to the wall still.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Tush tush, these are toys, I will none of these Flip-flaps, I will have no sopping, no puffs, nor no Cobwebs: no busks nor burbarrels: thou shalt wear thine own hair, and fine cloth of Sheepskins: thy colour shall be Dowlas, as white as a Lily: I will kiss these chop-cherries, thou shalt go Gossip at Shrovetide, look about to my Guests then.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: Aye, it was my hard fortune to be an Hostess, time was I might have done otherwise.

sp.speaker: City w:
sp.p: Why how now Woman, at the old disease still? will it never be better? cannot a Woman find one kind man amongst twenty? ah the days: I have seen, when a Woman's will was a law: if I had had a mind to such a thing, or such a thing, I could have had it, but it was never better since men were Purse-bearers.

sp.speaker: Hosty.
sp.p: Mine is even the unnaturalest man to his Wife

sp.speaker: Citie wi:
sp.p: Truly, and commonly are all such fat men: I will tell thee Gossip, I have buried six, I fix husbands, but if I should live to have as many more, as I know not what may happen, but sure I would never have such a fat man: they be the most unwieldy men, that women shall not want a sore stomach that is troubled with them I warrant her.
And he maintains me here like I know not what.

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: Aye, and what say, they are their wives head, well, if he be the head, she is the body, and the body is to bear the head, and the body is to bear the purse.
They cannot miss us, yet they regard us not.

sp.speaker: City wife.
sp.p: Miss us! no faith, but would all women were of my mind, they call us the weaker vessels: they should find vessels of us, but no weak vessels I warrant them.

sp.speaker: Pren.
sp.p: Mistress my Master calls for ye.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: Go, I will come anon, he is not so hasty to give me what I want I warrant ye,

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: No, would he were, little thinks the husband what goes through the wives hand washing, wringing and rubbing, up early, down late, and a thousand things they look not too.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: And yet they must have the government of all.

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: And great reason they have for it, but a wise man will put in a Woman's hand, what? she will save that he spends.
You have a pretty Ruff, how deep is it?

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: Nay this is but shallow, marry I have a Ruff is a quarter deep, measured by the yard.
Indeed by the yard!

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: By the standard, you have a pretty set too: how big is the steel you set it with?

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: As big as a reasonable sufficient ---

sp.speaker: Pren.
sp.p: Mistress, my Master would desire you to come in.

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: What? she shall not come yet, if you lay down the bucklers you lose the victory.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: By my troth I must go, we shall have such a coil else.

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: A coil! why have you not a tongue in your head? faith if ye win not all at that weapon, ye are not worthy to be a Woman, you hear not the news abroad:

sp.speaker: Hostess:
sp.p: No, what news?

sp.speaker: City wife.
sp.p: No, I warrant ye, you never come abroad, this is to be troubled with a fat man, he never comes abroad himself, nor suffers his wife out of his sight: ye shall ever have a fat Host, either on his bench at the door, or in his chair in the chimney, and there he spits and spawls a room like twenty Tobacco takers, O fie on them beasts.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: But I prithee what news?

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: O woman! the most hard favoured news, and without all conscience, they say there is a statute made any woman that buries her husband, is not to marry again of two months after.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: A tedious time by Lady, a month were enough.

sp.speaker: Cittie w.
sp.p: Aye half a month, winter nights are long, and cold, I will tell ye, I have buried six, and I thank my good fortune, I ever knew the next ere the other was in his winding sheet.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Mistress, my master is angry, and the Guests call for their Hostess.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: Go, I come, Gossip when shall I see you age?

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: Nay, when shall I see you abroad, seldom I am sure.
I must needs away, God buy you Gossip.

sp.speaker: Cittie w.
sp.p: God buy ye, Gods so, I have forgot wherefore I came: a word ere you go, the party ye wot on commends him unto ye, he that met the other party in the white felt, the yellow scarf, and the round Venetian, when the other party kissed you, and I broke the jest on him: when he said, kisses kindles Coals, and love searches.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p:
O! I remember him, yes faith, he is pretty well set: he has the right trick with the tongue in his
kiss, and he dances reasonably comely, but he falls heavy.

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: He savours of a kind of Gallant, but not of a Courtier.
Well, we will have a night of it, god be with ye Gossip.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: God buy ye.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p:
Not yours nor her own Terentia, yours in modesty Flauia,
See Tulley what an active passive love hath played, I love, and am again beloved, but at the shrine Where I do offer up my Cordial sacrifice, I am returned with peremptory scorn, And where I stand but as a gazer, Viewing all alike, I am pursued With violent passions a speaking eye Binds favours, and now discovering lines, Thy counsel now dear friend, for at Thy direction stands my thrall or freedom.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: O my Lord, affection is unlimited, Daring all dangers, having nor type nor figure, but beyond all art, Then tie not that (great Lord) to Tullies awe, Fancy forswears all reason, love all law.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p:
How well thy power can shun, that which I follow with obedience, too true i'faith, Thou mightst as well put out the eye of day,
Or cover sin from heaven, or to erect A tower of sand, on the uncertain surge, Or anything that were more inficient, Than to remove one doting thought of mine From her disdain, thy aide dear Tulley.
Be thou an Orator for Lentulus, My tongue stands tuned to a harsher method, Breath in her ears those Organs of receipt, A quintessence distilled of honey words, And charm with a beguiling lullaby, Her free consent to thine and my request. Which done, that is done, which is my sole delight, Which done, that is done, that I can never quite.

sp.speaker: Tull:
sp.p: All which to me are problematic mines, Obscured enigmas, and to my studies Incognite language: yet if my powers, Have power to cloth my tongue in love, I will be a Lover, and in love so plead, As if that Tully loved Terentia.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p:
Thanks sweet Cicero, this day we dine with old Flamiuius,
The forward Father of my Awkward love. His willing mind doth strive to make the peace, Betwixt our discord thoughts: his free consent Is given to Lentulus, there Tulley taketh on hold,
And when a Sun of thy intent shines fair, Onset loves fort, with politic assaults, And conquer conquest in obtaining that, Where victors are repulsed: but see, Our talk hath overtaken our way, see old Flaminius Comes to welcome us, With him a look, look the bright orient verge, At the uprising of Auroraes shine.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: And my good Lord, you are happily met. Heartily welcome: young Tullie welcome too, ye come well to ease my charge, these Ladies find fault with their Guardian, I go too softly for them: old blood is stiff, and young Ladies will not bear with age: I resign, I resign to you that follow.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p:
If they admit us for their Guardian,
We will dare dangers ere we part from them.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Why well said my Lords, Soldiers will not fly indeed, I have seen the day I could have cracked a tree of yew, made my bowstring, whisper in mine ear if they twang: tossed my pike lustily: it is since the siege of Parthia, by the mass a great while, I was lusty then, at the service was done there, yet I love the discourse: come my Lord, I choose your company, leave Tulley to the Ladies, he can tell them tales of Venus and Adonis, and that best pleaseth them. Now I must hear of raps and blows, and Bills and Guns, and swords and bucklers: I loved it once, come, our Cooks are backward, discourse will beget stomachs, you are like to tarry long for lean Cates.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Now gentle Tulley, advocate my suite, Her fore amazing person makes me mute.

sp.speaker: Cicero.
sp.p: I will bear these Ladies company, If they shall deem acceptance.

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.p: With interest of thanks to Cicero,

sp.speaker: Flau:
sp.p: Faith I like not this odds of female, an equality were better: yet of both it were fitter the woman should undergo the odds, I had rather he said three men to one woman, than two women to one man: here is Tulley addressed to Terentia, Terentia drawing near to Tully: here is small comfort left for Flauia, well gentles, I will leave ye to the Goddess: so ho my Lords, take me with ye.

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.p: Nay, stay good Flauia, You will not lose the sight of Lentulus.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Nor you of Tulley, come if you tell, I will blab.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: But sweet Lady, Tully is not here.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: But Cicero is, his near friend, that is as good.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: He was Lady, till he changed his habit, by putting on the office of an unskilful Serving-man, intending to guard Terentia to her fathers house.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Then Flauia must guard herself: well, use good words, and good action, and stalk well before your Lady, she is kind in faith, and a little thing will please her.

sp.speaker: Terent.
sp.p: Will it please Flauia to partake?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: O fie, it were an injury, I could brook myself therefore, I will leave ye, but be brief, stand not on points, cut them all first, and if ye fall to kissing, kiss not too long for fear ye kiss the post.

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.p: Go to, you will still be a wag Flauia. But what says Tulley to Terentia?

sp.speaker: Cicero.
sp.p: Lady I must maintain my former argument, Tulley is not here, but here is Tullies friend, For ere I speak, I must entreat, you will Transform poor Tulley into Lentulus.

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.p: I have no power of Metamorphosing, If Tulley be not here, you must conceal, I cannot make of Tulley Lentulus.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p:
Nor can the world make Cicero so worthy, Yet for an hour discourse a Peasant; shape, Nay represent the person of a king. Then in the person of great Lentulus, I do salute Sun-bright Terentia, Lady, vouchsafe a Saint-like smile on him, From that angel form; whose honoured mind Lies prostrate lowly at Terentias feet, Who hath put off a Golden victors honour, And left the Parthyan spoil to Lepido,
Whom many Ladies have bedecked with favours, Of rich esteem, O proud! he deigned to wear them, Yet gifts and givers he did slight esteem. For why? the purpose of his thoughts were bent, To seek the love of fair Terentia. The choice is such, as choicer cannot be, Even with a nimble eye his virtues, through His smile is like the Meridian Sol, Discerned a dancing in the burbling brook: His frown out-dares the Austerest face, Of war or Tyranny: to seize upon His shape might force the Virgin huntress
With him for ever live a vestal life, His mind is virtues overmatched yet this and more Shall die, if this and more want force, To win the love of fair Terentia, Then gentle Lady, give a gentle dome, Never was breast the Landlord to a heart, More loving, faithful, or more loyal, Than is the breast of noble.

sp.speaker: Teren:
sp.p: Tullie.

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: Lentulus!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: And why not Tullie?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: It stands not aptly.

sp.speaker: Tere:
sp.p: It wants a syllable.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: It doth.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Then noble Cicero.

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: That is too dear.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Gentle is as good, Then say the best of gentle Cicero.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Good Lady wrong not your honour so, To seat unworthy Tulley with your worth, O look upon the worth of Lentulus, Let your fair hand be beam unto the balance, And with a steadied peise, lift up that beam, In on the scale, put the worth of Lentulus His state, his honours, and his revenues, Against that heavy wait: put poverty, The poor and naked name of Cicero, A partner of unregarded Orators, Then shall you see with what celerity, One title of his worth will soon pull up, Poor Tullies dignity.

sp.speaker: Tere:
sp.p: Just to the height of Terentias heart, Where I will keep and Character that name, And to that name my heart shall add that love, That shall weigh down the worth of Lentulus.

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: Dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p:
Speak still if thou wilt, but not for him, The more thou speakest, the more augments my love,
If that thou canst add more to infinite, The more thou speakest, the more decreaseth his, If thou canst take away, aught from nothing, Think Tulley, if Lentulus can love me, So much and more, Terentia doth love thee.

sp.speaker: Tull:
sp.p: O Madam! Tulley is poor, and poor is counted base.

sp.speaker: Ter:
sp.p: Virtue is rich and blots a poor disgrace.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Lentulus is great, his frown is my woe, And of a friend he will become my foe.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: As he is friend, we will entreat his love, As he is great, his threatenings shall not make me love.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Your fathers grant, makes Lentulus your Lord,

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.p: But if thereto his daughter not accord, That grant is canceled, fathers may command, Life before love, for life to true love is pawned.

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: How will Flaminius brooke my poverty?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Well, when Flaminius sees no remedy, Lord how woman like are men, when they are wooed? Tully, weigh me not light, never did immodest blush Colour these cheeks, but ardent.

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: Silence sweet Lady, here comes Flauia.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p:
Fie, fie, how tedious ye are: yonder is great looking for Tulley, the old Senate has put on his spectacles, and Lentulus and he are turning the leaves of a doghay,
leaves of a worm eaten Chronicle, and they want Tullies judgment.

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: About what sweet Lady?

sp.speaker: Fla:
sp.p: To know what year it was the showers of rain fell in April:

sp.speaker: Tul:
sp.p: I can resolve it by rote Lady, it was that year the Cuckoo sung in May: another token Lady, there reigned in Rome a great Tyrant that year, and many Maids lost their heads for using flesh on Fish days.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: And some were sacrificed as a burnt offering to the Gods of Hospitality, were they not?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: You are a wag Flauia, but talk and you, must needs have a parting blow:

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: No matter so we stand out and close not.

sp.speaker: Tull:
sp.p: Or part fair at the close and to it again.

sp.speaker: Flau:
sp.p: Nay, if we should to it again Terentia would grow jealous.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Ladies, I take my leave, And my love.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Take heed ye sigh not, nor look red at the table Tully.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Your shoe wrings you Lady.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Go to, ye are a wanton Flauia.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: How now Terentia, in your nine Muses? There is none must plead in your case but an Orator.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: \ I want one indeed Wench, but thou hast two, and the gentle destinies may send thee three, never blush: for smoke and the fire of a woman's love cannot be hid. O a fine tongue, dipped in Helicon, a comedian tongue is the only persuasive ornament to win a Lady, why his discourse is as pleasant ---

sp.speaker: Fla:
sp.p: As how I prithee?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: And keeps as good decorum; his prologue with obedience to the skirt, a rough Scene of civil Wars, with a clapping conclusion, perhaps a Jig, if not the Tragicomical Tale of Mars and Venus, then must she take the Tale by the end, where he defending Mars, and she Venus, must fall from billing to biting, from biting to blows, to get the supremacy.

sp.speaker: Fla:
sp.p: A good policy to praise Cicero, For fear I rob you of your Lentulus.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p:
Faith a Soldier is not for thy humour, now I cry a Warrior, he fights stoutly in a field bed, discharges his work sure, under his Curtains would I fight, but come, our Lovers melt while we meditate; thou for thy
scholar, I for my soldier: and if we cannot please them so, we will shake off this loose habit, and turn Pages to please their humours.

sp.speaker: Grae.
sp.p: Come Accutus, discharge your follower, let us leave rubbing a while, since the bias runs so much the wrong way: Sirrah, these bowls which we roll and turn in our lower sphere, are by use made wooden worldlings right for everyone strives who shall ye nearest the mistress.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: They post indeed, as their nature is, in an even way, but they are cowards, they will abide no danger, they rub at every molehill, and if they tire in going up a hill, they retire and come back again.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Well, let them alley, bet all, then to rest, away, begone.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: 'sfoot Graccus, here is a couple of oar old gamesters, O for quick conceit to beget a jest: here is two that either a man must be acquainted or quarrel with, and of two evils I will chose the latter, I hope to make it the lesser: if I should be acquainted, the fool will haunt me: if I quarrel, I may be so blessed as to be rid of a fool.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: I have a woman's wit for a sudden stratagem.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: No by my troth, by this bright horrison ---

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: An excellent Cuckoo, he keeps his note in Winter.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I have no appetite at all to live in the country any more: now as they say, I have got a smack on the Cittie, 'slid I think (as the proverb goes) I was wrapped in my mothers mock the day I was begotten, I thank the Goddess Cupid for it, I am so favoured of the Women, my hostess loves me execrably.

sp.speaker: Accut:
sp.p: Good reason, fools make good sport.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: Sever, sever, ere we be discovered.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Sir, the respective regard of your well governed parts do challenge a mellifluous species of enduement,
or contumelious estimation.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: Gentles, God save ye, well overtaken Gallants.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Welcome by the welkin.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: It is a very pleasant weather.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, the air is frugal.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Is that Gentleman of your Company?

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Our company sir, no, we are no companions for lame Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Proper man, pity he is so regardless: a good leg, it seems he has some grief in it.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Nay, and he be lame I will talk to him, there is so many lusty knaves walks now a days, will not stick to give a man hard words, if he be not disposed to charity: hark ye sir, I understand ye are a proper man, and that you have a good leg.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: And what of that Sir?

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: What of that? 'slid he answers me like a sturdy beggar already: by the five elements or senses; I ask ye for no hurt, I would bestow my charity as frank as ---

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Stoop and look out, 'swounds a Gentleman cannot come by a misfortune in service or so, but every fool will ride him take that ---

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Sirrah, stay, I will combat thee in his defence.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Sir, be pacifical, the impotent must be lightly regarded.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Give me leave Gentlemen, I will follow him.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Nay, I pray you be malcontented, I have no great hurt: but in revenge he is a rascal for using me so, he may thank God, discretion governed me, it is well known I have always been a man of peace, I will not strike ye the least mouse in anger, nor hurt the poorest Cony that goes in the street, for I know of fighting comes quarrelling, of quarrelling comes brawling, and of brawling grows hard words, and as the learned puerelis writes, it is good sleeping in a whole skin.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Sir, your discretion shall govern me at this time, your name I pray ye sir?

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: My name is seignior Scillicet.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Even so sir? nay sir, I do not forget your Argument.

sp.speaker: Acut;
sp.p: Save ye sir, saw you not a Gentleman come this way even now, somewhat hurt in the one of his Legs?

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: He went by even now sir, is he a friend of yours?

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: A dear friend, and a proper Gentleman sir.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: By the horizon he is a proper man indeed, he gave me the time of the day, as he went by: I have a gallon of wine for him at any time, If ye see anything in me worth commendations, I pray ye commend me to him.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: I will sir, it were best you gave me good words, but I will try ye farther yet, fare ye well sir.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I pray you remember me to him, you see my anger is over already.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Sir, I did not note ye, what fellow was that?

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Sir, he is a friend of his, that struck me even now.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Would ye not strike him? let us follow.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Indeed ye shall not, I hate it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will not be barren of my armoury, in my future perambulation for the lower element.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: You are too patient in wrongs sir, 'swounds I know not how to pick a quarrel.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: Sir, the grievous youth is inwardly possessed with a supple spirit, he can brooke impugning, but it is adverse to my spirit if I were armed.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Save ye gallants, saw ye not a fellow come halting this way of late?

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Hath he done any hurt, or is he a friend of yours?

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: He is a Rascal, and I will maintain him so.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: He is a very Rascal indeed, and he used me like a knave: if ever I meet him I shall hardly put it up, I have it in black and blew to show here.

sp.speaker: Serr,
sp.p: Say I breath defiance to his front.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Challenge him the field.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Dost think he will answer me? I will challenge him at the pitchfork, or the Flail, or I will wrestle a fall with him for a bloody nose, any weapon I have been brought up in, I will ---

sp.speaker: Accut:
sp.p: What will ye? here he is, you minim that will be friend with friends, and foe with foes, and you that will defy Hercules, and outbrave Mars, and fears not the Devil, pass bladder I will make ye swell.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: By Gods-lid if I had known it had been you, I would not have said so to your face.

sp.speaker: Accut:
sp.p: Away with your Champion, go.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: This was excellently performed, i'faith a better breathing than a game at bowls.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: They will give you the good salve any time this month, for I am sure they have salving enough for so long.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: I pity the fool i'faith, but the the other Horse-leech, I wish his blows trebled: I conversed with him, but a Rogue so stuffed with a library of new minted words, so tearing the sense, I never met with.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: But now we have spoiled our determinate dinner at my hostess of the Hobby, we shall now be known.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: That holds well still, I am taken for a proved friend, and thou shalt be disguised till I have wrought a league by virtue of a pottle of Canary.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Content, mine Host shall be accessory, and I will be a servitor to observe miracles.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: They are good subjects for idle hours: but soft what second course is entering here?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: For I did but kiss her: Boss, how likest thou my relish?

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: O Sir, relish but your liquor as you do your song, you may go drunk to bed any day in the week.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Sister awake, close not, etcetera does my face hold colour still?
Aye, and you would but scavenge the pavilion of your nose.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Aye marry Accutus how likest thou this Gentlewoman Gallant?

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: A good states man, for common wealth of Brownists, the Rogue hates a Church like a Counter.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Aye, and if my Lady Argentile were dead, he would rather live upon alms than fall to work,

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: So: he might have toleration, What, shall us close with them?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: In any case, but in some mild embrace, for if we should continue thus rough, we should be shunned like an Apoplexy.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Gallants, the fortune of the day runs with ye, what all at mum chance? how is it? how is it?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Sir, I think it was you bestowed some abuse of me the other day.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: Which I would wipe out of your memory with satisfaction of a double courtesy.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I accept it i'faith sir, I am not prone to anger, I assure ye the following night knew not my anger: your acquaintance Seignior.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Fie, without ceremony; let us yoke this triplicity as we did in the days of old, with mirth and melody.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p:
Aye, say you so? then Coll her and clip her, and kiss
her too, etcetera
The triplicity, here is those has supped at an ordinary.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: This gallant humours.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: But the other walks a loose.
The triplicity, here is those has cracked Glasses, and drawn blood of a Tapster.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: The visitation of your hand sir.
The triplicity, will colours change?

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Sir, take no offence I beseech ye, we gave only satisfaction for an old injury, but in the degree of amity yourself sits in the superlative.
Not so sir, but in respect.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: What kind is your Dog of Sir?

sp.speaker: Boss:
sp.p: Very kind to anything but his meat, that he devours with great alacrity.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Where was he bred?
In a Bitch.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: What country?
A kind of Mongrel, he will carry, but not fetch, marry he is to be put to a dancing school for instruction.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: The trick of the rope were excellent in him, and that I will teach him if I miss not my mark: come Gallants, we waste time, the first Tavern we arrive at, we will see the race of an hourglass.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Can ye a part in a Song?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Very tolerably.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: We will have a catch then, if with sol, sol, la: Gentlemen, have you any good herb? you have match boy,

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Your pipe shall want no fire sir.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: O without ceremony: now Graccus, if we can but pawn their senses in Sacks and Sugar, let me alone to pursue the sequel.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Follow it, away.

div2.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter Hostess, Cittizens wife, Scruulus and Scillicet.

sp.speaker: Hostess:
sp.p: Come, come, bring them out of the air: alas good hearts, what rogorous villain would commit with him? I will tell ye Gossip, he is even as kind an animal, he would not wrong them i'faith.

sp.speaker: City wife.
sp.p: Tush, fear nothing woman, I hope to make him so again: alack, alack, how fell you out, all at head? O Butcher! are ye hurt in another place?

sp.speaker: Hostess:
sp.p: Did he not throw you against the stones? If he did, do not conceal, I dare say you gave them not a foul word.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: By the illuminate welkin not a word till my mouth was full of blood, and so made my words foul.

sp.speaker: City wife.
sp.p: Is not this Gentleman hurt too?

sp.speaker: Serr:
sp.p: Only the extravagant Attire of my arm is bruised.

sp.speaker: Cittie wi:
sp.p: See, see, the extravagant of his arm is bruised too, alas how could ye quarrel so?

sp.speaker: Serr:
sp.p: I will demonstrate, in defence of the generous youth, I did oppugn, my adverse let violently fly.

sp.speaker: City wife:
sp.p: Ah good hearts! would I had stood between you when he let fly so violently.

sp.speaker: Ser:
sp.p: We void of hostile arms.
Aye, if they had had horses, they had saved their arms.

sp.speaker: Serr:
sp.p: Be capable, I mean, void of armoury.

sp.speaker: City wife:
sp.p: Until ye had had armour on.

sp.speaker: Serr:
sp.p: Had I been accompanied with my Toledo, or morglay ---

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: Aye, your Dog or Bitch:

sp.speaker: Serr:
sp.p: Continue I beseech, I mean my sword, sole lie my sword:

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: Or solely your sword, better a bad tool than none at all.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: In the concourse.

sp.speaker: Cittie w.
sp.p: Nay, the concourse will light on him for it I warrant.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: Aye, for the tuition of my Capital, did mount my Semisphere three degrees, that as a strong and stony guard did defend my Capital.

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: It was well ye kept him out, for if he had entered on your stony Guard, he would have spoiled your Capital.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: In fine being mortally assailed, he did perambulate or walk off.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Yes faith, he did perambulate, and walk me finely.

sp.speaker: Cittie w
sp.p: Good hearts, how many were there of them?

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: About the number of seven.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Aye there was seven.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: Or eight.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Or eight.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: Rather more.

sp.speaker: City w.
sp.p: Aye more at least I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p:
Alas ye cannot choose but be more hurt, but
I will search you thoroughly be assured.

sp.speaker: City w:
sp.p: And if she cannot help ye, few can, she knows what belongs to a Tent or a bruise, and experience is good in those cases.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: I have a concupiscent form of trust in your skill, it will maladies.

sp.speaker: City wi.
sp.p: I fear not, put both your concupiscence in me for that matter.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: The generous will disburse coinage for satisfaction of your metaphysical endeavour,

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I will discharge all.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: We make no doubt of that, come into a chamber, ye shall lie down awhile, perhaps you will be stiff anon, then you shall use your legs, the more you strive with it, the better, alas good hearts.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: So, sol, lo, Tapster, give attendance Gentlemen, I hope all we are friends, the welkin is sky colour still, and men must grow by degrees, you must pardon me, I must sp --- speak my mind.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: The uttermost of your mind at this time cannot be offensive.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: The fryer was in the sol, sol, draw the the other quart, I hope you are not angry gallants? and ye come to my lodging, ye shall be welcome, my Hostess shall bid you welcome: she is a good wench, if I say the word, she will fa-full fill it.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Sirrah drawer, for the other that is asleep, let him so remain: for the Dog let him be bound to a post for his appearance, till I take order for his undoing.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The fool and the Dog shall both take rest at your command Sir.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I hope we are all friends, sol, sol, shall us have a catch?

sp.speaker: Gra:
sp.p: Aye, come come, everyone, catch a part.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Hey good boys i'faith, now a three man's song, or the old down a down: well, things must be as they may, fills the other quart, muscadine with an egg is fine, there is a time for all things, bonos nocthus.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Good night to you sir.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p:
So, now Graccus see, what a polluted lump, A deformed Chaos of unsteady earth Man is, being in this ill kind unmad, seeming something Bestial man, brutish animal: well it is thus decreed He shall be what he seems, that is dead. For what in him shows life, but a breathing air, Which by a free constraint itself engenders In things without life: as betwixt a pair of bellows We feel a forcible air, having of itself Force and being, no more is this breathing block, But for his use in kind: give out in some burse or congregation
Among the multitude, Philantus death. Let all the customary rights of funeral,
His knell or what else be solemnly observed, I will take order for his winding sheet: And further, to furnish it with further surety, I will have a potion, that for twenty hours, Shall quench the motion of his breath. Go, spread, let me alone to effect it.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I will sow it I warrant thee, thou talkest of burse, I have away worth ten of it, I will first give it out in my Barbers shop, then at my ordinary, and that is as good as a broad: and as I cross Tiber, my waterman shall attach it, he will send it away with the tide, then let it come out to an Oyster wenches ear, and she will cry it up and down the streets.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Let us first secure him from eyes, and at night he shall be portered to our chamber: so, now away.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: O a couple that would spread early, let us give it for loves sake.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Call, call,

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Hem, hem.

sp.speaker: Cittiy wife.
sp.p: A pox on your hemmings, do you think we care for your hemmings,

sp.speaker: Hostess:
sp.p: It is some stinking troublesome knave I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: City wife:
sp.p: Hang him, regard him not, there is hemming indeed like a Cat, (God bless us) with a bur in her throat.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: 'sheart, how we are ripped-up for this?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
O man, this hemming is the most hatefullest thing, there is not the most public punk, nor worm-eaten bawd that can abide it, and honesty would run mad to hear it, but come, we waste, time, it is now about the mid of day, we must sow arithmetic by the hours, that let the morrows height Philantus awake again, at which time he shall be on his Hearse, and all the Guests of the Hobby invited
to accompany his ghost, when being awake himself, and all shall see, if drunkenness be not mad mystery.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: But I prithee practise some milder behaviour at the ordinary, be not all madman.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Push, I will be all observative, and yet i'faith I grieve to see this double guarded age, all side coat, all fool, fie, thou keepest the sports from the mark, away, and return what news is now in progress.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: I have the newest, Terentia Daughter to the old Senate, though Lentulus left the field to come to her, yet she hath forsaken him in the open field, and she is for our young Orator Tully, she has vowed by Venus leg, and the little God of Love, he shall be her captain, she will serve under him till death us depart, and thereto I plight thee my troth.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: More Ladies Terentias, I cry still, That prise a Saint before a Silken fool, She that loves true learning and pomp disdains, Treads on Tartarus, and Olimpus gains.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Aye marry, but then would learning be in colours proud, proud, then would not four nobles purchase a benefice, two Sermons in a year.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Aye Graccus, now thou hittest the finger right, Upon the shoulder of Ingratitude: Thou hast clapped an action of flat felony Now ill be tide that partial judgment, That dooms a farmers rich, adultus, to the supremacy of a Deanery. When needy, yet true grounded Discipline, Is governed with a thread bare Vicarage.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Aye thou speakest well of their sides that are liberally overseen in the sciences, I take no hold on it, but were all men of thy mind, then would every Schoolmaster be a Senate, and there would never come Cobbler to be Constable again.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p:
Enough, enough Graccus, let silence seal up Our secret thoughts, and liberty say,
Virtus sola summa gloria,
Que format homines, vera honore.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Go to I say, urge no more, it is Tavern talk, for Taverners Table talk for all, the vomit of rumour: what news says one? none so new as this, Tully shall be married to Terentia: what news says another? the same, the same, whose consent have ye? not mine, I deny it, I must know of it, I will have a hand, go to, no more.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Gentle sir, Lay not that leaden load of foul reproach, Upon so weak a prop, what is done is past recall, If aught is done, unfitting to be done, The worst is done, my life must answer it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
Tul.
sp.p: Reverend Sir be more patient.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I am impatient: I am troubled: I am vexed: I am scoffed: I am pointed at: I will not endure it: I will not abide it: I will be revenged, I will: of her: of you both: proud boy: wanton giglot, aspiring haughty, know your equals, she is not for ye, if ye persist, by my holy maker you shall answer it, look to it, you shall, you shall indeed.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p:
I shall, I must, I will, I will indeed,
Even to the greatest I will answer it: If great men's ears be ope to innocency, If greatness be not partial with greatness, Even to the greatest I will answer it, Perhaps some shallow we censurer will say, The Orator was proud, he would climb too hie: But heaven and truth will say the contrary.
My greatest grief is, I have my friend betrayed, The treason is done, Aye, and the Traitor is free, Yet innocent Treason needs not to flee, His loyalty bids me abide his frown, And he hath power to raise, or hurl me down.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: What ails my Tully, wherefore lookest thou sad? What discontent hath stopped the crimson current Which ran so cheerfully within that brow, And makes it sullen like a standing poole? Tell me, who is it hath wrong my Cicero?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: O wrong him not.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Who is it then that wrongs my Tully so? What hath Terentia aught offended thee? Dost thou recall thy former promises? Dost thou repent thee of ---

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: O wrong me not.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p:
What hath my Father done this injury? There, there, thy thoughts accord to say it is so,
I will deny him then, he is not my father, He is not my friend will envy Cicero.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Wrong not thyself.

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.p: What heavy string dost thou divide upon? Wrong not him, wrong not me, wrong not thyself, Where didst thou learn that doleful mandrakes note, To kill the hearers? Tully, Canst thou not endure a little danger for my love? The fiery spleen of an angry Father, Who like a storm will soon consume itself, I have endured a thousand jarring hours, Since first he did mistrust my fancies aim: And will endure a thousand thousand more, If life or discord either live so long.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: The like will I for sweet Terentia, Fear not, I have approved armour on, Will bide the brunt of popular reproach, Or whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Enough Tully, we are discovered.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Ye faith, are ye at it? what is there never a loving tear shed on neither side? nor you? nor you? Tullies are red, come, come ye fools, be more brief, I would have buried three husbands before you will be married.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Why lives Flauia a Virgin still?

sp.speaker: Fla:
sp.p: Because I have vowed virginity till I can get a husband

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.p: Why Flauia you have many suitors.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: O I am laden with suitors: for indeed I am fain to bear with any of them, I have a dumb show of all their pictures, each has sent in his several shadow, and I swear I had rather have them than the substance of any of them.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Can you not describe them in action?

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Yes, and their action: I have one honest man of the age of forty five or there about, that traverses his ground three mile every morning to speak to me, and when he is come; after the saluting ceremony of how do you Lady, he falls to calculating the nativity of the Moon, prognosticating what fair weather will follow, if it either snow or rain, sometime with a gentle pinch by the finger, intermixed with the valley of sighs: he falls to discoursing of the price of peas, and that is as pleasing to me as a stinking breath.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: A good description.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Another brings Letters of commendation from the Constable of the Parish, or the Churchwarden, of his good behaviour and bringing up, how he could write and read written hand: further, desiring that his Father would request my Father that his Fathers Son might marry my Fathers Daughter, and he will make her a jointer of a hundred pound a year, and beget three or four fools to boot.

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.p: Better and better.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p:
Vjus promptus facit.
Faemina ludificantur viros, well, forward,

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: I have another, that I prise dearer than the rest, a most sweet youth, and if the wind stand with him I can smell him half a mile ere he come at me, indeed he wears a Musk cat, what call ye it about him?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: What do you call it?

sp.speaker: Flau:
sp.p: What ye will, but he smells better than burnt Rosemary, as well as a perfuming pan, and every night after his first sleep, writes lovesick sonnets, railing against left handed fortune his foe, that suffers his sweet heart to frown on him so.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Then it seems you grant him no favour.

sp.speaker: Flau:
sp.p: Faith I dare not venture on him for fear he should be rotten: give me nature, not art.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Here comes Lord Lentulus.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Swift danger now ride post through this passage, health to your honour.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And happiness to you.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: It is heaven dear Lord, but ---

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Tush, tush, on earth, come, come, I know your suite, it is granted sure what ever it be.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: My suit craves death for treason to my friend.

sp.speaker: Teren.
sp.p: The Traitor lives while I have breath to spend, Then let me die to satisfy your will.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Neither i'faith, kneel not, rise, rise, I pray You both confess you have offended me.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We do, we have.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Then for this offence, be this your doom, Tulley must die, but not till fates decree To cut your vital thread, or Terentia Find in her heart to be your Deathsman?

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Faith the Fates may do as they may, but Terentia will never find in her heart to kill him, she will first bury him quick.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: The like is doomed to fair Terentai, How say you both, are ye content?

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: My thoughts are plunged in admiration.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: But can your honour bury such a wrong?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I can, I can, here Tully, take Terentia, Live many happy years in faithful love, This is no more than friendships laws allow, Think me thyself another Cicero.

sp.speaker: Flau:
sp.p: It were better my Lord, you did persuade her to think you another Cicero, so you might claim some interest in her now and then.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p:
That I would claim with you, fair Lady, hark
in your ear, nay, I must conclude with you.

sp.speaker: Flau:
sp.p: You will not bite my Lord?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: No, of my faith my Lady.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Thus far my love, our hopes have good success, One storm more past, my griefs were much the less.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Friendship itself hath been more prodigal, Than a bold face could beg upon a friend.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Why then, there is a bargain.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Strike hands upon the same, I am yours to command. I will love with ye, I will lie with ye, I will love with all my heart, With all my strength, with all my power and virtue: Sealed and delivered in the presence of us:

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Marcus, Tullius, and Cicero. Then you deliver this as your act and deed?

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: I do, and seal it with this ---

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Why well said, it is done, see, we begin but now, And are as ready to go to Church as you: What needs further ceremony?

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Yes, a little matrimony.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Aye Lady, come Tully and Terentia, One day shall shine on both our Nuptials, Fear not, I will quench the fire of your Fathers heat With my consent.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: I prithee appoint the time.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: About a week hence love.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: O, it is too intolerable long.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Then four days.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Four days is four times four and twenty hours that is too long too.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: We cannot sooner be ready:

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Yes and unready too, in a day and a half.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Well then two days.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.p: Till then we will feed on conceit, Tully thank me but for your company, I would not tarry so long: come Tully since we shall be married all at one time, we will go to bed so, and he shall be master of the Cockpit, that bids his Gossips first.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Nay quick Graccus, lest our hour forestall us, I will in and deal for your disguise, tarry thou, and give mine host a share of our intent, marry charge him to keep it as secret as his Garbage. He undoes our drift and clothes the fool in sackcloth during his life.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I will warrant thee I will manage it with as good judgment as a Constable his charge.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: And I mine as a watchman his office.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Better I hope: well about it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: There, there, my little lackey boys, give the word as ye pass, look about to my guests there, score up at the Bar there; again, again my fine Mercuries; if you will live in the faculty be ruled by instructions: you must be eyed like a Sergeant, an ear like a Bell-founder, your conscience a Schoolmaster, a knee like a Courtier: a fool like a Lackey, and a tongue like a Lawyer, away, away, my brave bullies: welcome sweet Seignior, I cannot bow to thy knee I am as stout and as stiff as a new made knight, but if I say the word mine Host bids the cobbler ---

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: May I crave a word of you mine Host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Thou shalt, whisper in mine ear, I will see and say little, what I say, does the mouse and welcome my bullies.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: By the torrid zone (sweetheart) I have thought well of you ever since I loved ye, as a man would say (like a young dancer out of all measure) if it please you i'faith, anything I have promised you, I will perform it to a hair, ere tomorrow night.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I wounder I can hear no news of my man and my puppy.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Do you think sweet heart, to be married by day light or by torch-light.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: By night is more Lady-like, I will have a crier to cry my puppy sure.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: What think ye if we had an offering?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: That were most base i'faith.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Base, 'slid I cannot tell, if it were as base as a sag but I will be sworn it is as common as a whore, it is even as common to see a Basin at the Church door as a box at a Playhouse.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: It grieves me not so much for my man, as for my puppy, my man can shift for himself, but my poor puppy, truly I think I must take Physic even for fear sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Tut, tut, I warrant thee, I will be as close as a bawd, I will keep mine own counsel, be merry and close, merry heart lives long, let my guests take no wrong, and welcome my bully.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: There is none meant believe it sir.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Seignior, by the welkin well met, what, all three so luckily?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Gallants, saving the Ceremony, Stroke your hair up and admire, forswear sack.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Forswear Sack, 'slid not for the spending of two farms more, if they were come into my hands once,

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I say be astonished, and forswear sack, for by the combustion influence of sack five men lie breathless, ready to be folded in the terrestrial element.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: Five slain with Sack, is it possible?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: These eyes are testators.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Nay then it is so.

sp.speaker: Getica:
sp.p: Sir, you have not heard of a puppy in your travels.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: No, indeed, Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Five believe me Sir.

sp.speaker: Acu:
sp.p:
Five of one, O devil! what limb of him but a complete Villain,
A tongue profaner than Idolatry: His eye a Beacon, fixed in his place: Discovering ills, but hood winked unto grace, Her heart a nest of vice, kept by the Devil, His good is none at all, his all, is evil,

sp.speaker: Hostess;
sp.p: O the father, Gallants, yonder is the most hard favoured news walks the streets, seven men going to their graves that died with drinking and bezzling.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Good still, nay, then I see the devil has some power over a woman more than a man, seven! it will be more anon.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Now I beseech Bacchus my puppy has not over seen himself.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: This is very strange.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: And as true a report I assure you.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: Out alas, where is my Gossip? O woman! have you not heard the news?
Yes, I have heard of it.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: O woman, did your childes child ever see the like, nine men to be buried today, that drunk healths last night.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p:
Better and better, goodness never mends so fast
in the carrying: nine!

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: They say one is your guest Philantus,

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: And all I dare swear, whom I will revive again

sp.speaker: Cittie wife
sp.p: Well, he was a proper man i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hostess:
sp.p: Aye, and had good skill in prick-song, yet he had a fault in his humour, as none are without (but Puritans:) he would swear like an Elephant, and stamp and stare (God bless us) like a playhouse bookkeeper, when the actors miss their entrance.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Nay hark ye sir, I can brooke much injury, but not that, meddle with me, but not with my trade, she is mine own, she is meus, tuus, suus, no man's else, I assure ye we are sure together.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Sure ye are together sir, but is your wife, your trade? you mean to live upon your wife then.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: The fool has some wit though his money be gone.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Sir, I hope ye are not offended, I assure ye would be loath to offend the least hair of your caput, sissiput, or occiput.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Occiput: what mean you by occiput?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: The former part of your head.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: The former part of your head, why I hope I have not an occiput, in the former part of my head, Seignior Seruulus, what means he by it?

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: The signification of the word only amounts to this, the former part of your head.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: The fool is jealous, prithee feed it.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: 'slid I cannot be so sussified, I pray you Seignior what means he by occuput?

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: No hurt verily, only, the word signifies, and the reason is (saith Varro ) being a great deriver from originals it is called occiput, for that the former part of the head looks likest the Ox.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Likest the Ox, by gad, if ever I come to talk with that Varro, I will make him show a better reason for it.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: But howsoever, it proceeded from me all in kindness.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: Sir, I accept it so, for I tell ye I am of a mollifying nature, I can strut, and again in kindness, I can suffer a man to break my head, and put it up without anger.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: I claim that privilege sir, I think I offended you once that way.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I love ye then for it sir, yet I cannot remember that ever a Tapster broke my head, yet I call to mind I have broke many Tapsters heads.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Not as a Tapster, for I but borrow this habit.

sp.speaker: Scil
sp.p: The fruit is known by the tree, by gad I knew by your apron ye were a gentleman, but specially by your flat cap.

sp.speaker: Serr.
sp.p: I call to memory, let us unite with kind embrace.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Now well fare your hearts, by my truth it is joy to a woman, to see men kind, faith you courtiers are mad fellows, you care not in your humours to stab man or woman that stands in your way, but in the end your kindness appears.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: You can resolve us sir, we hear of great revels to be at Court shortly.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: At the marriage of Lentulus, and the Orator: very true.
Might not a company of Wives be beholding to thee for places that would be there without their husbands knowledge if need were?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: A moiety of friendship that, I will place ye where ye shall sit and see all.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: Sit nay if there were but good standings, we care not.

sp.speaker: Acu:
sp.p: 'sfoot Graccus we tarry too long I fear, the hour will over take us, tarry thou and invite the Guests, and I will go see his course mounted.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: About it.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: Whether goes that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p:
About a needful trouble: this gentleman Hath at the charges of his charity, Prepared to inter, a friend of his,
Though lately entertained a friend of yours. Acquaintance to you all, Philantus: and would desire You would with him accompany his ghost To funeral, which will be presently on his journey.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Of his charge, died he not able to purchase a Winding sheet?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: It were sin to wrong the dead, you shall hear the inventory of his pocket. Inprimis, A brush and a Comb. --- o --- o --- five pence. Item, a looking Glass. --- o --- o --- one halfpenny. Item, A case of Tobacco Pipes. --- o --- o --- four pence. Item, Tobacco half an ounce. --- o --- o --- sixpence Item, in money and gold. --- o --- o --- threepence Summa totalis. nineteen pence half penny.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: What was his suite worth?

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: His suit was cold, because not his own, and the owner caused it to be restored as part of recompense, having lost the principal.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: What, are they ready: the Corse is on his journey hitherwards.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Tush, two women's tongues give as loud report as a camp royal of double cannons.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Tut, tut, thou art welcome, Cornutus is my neighbour, I love him as myself, thou hast a shrew to thy wife, gave her tongue too much string, but let mine Host give thee counsel, he will teach thee a remedy.

sp.speaker: Cornu.
sp.p: No, no, my good Host, mum, mum, no words against my wife, she is mine own, one flesh and one blood, I shall feel her hurt, her tongue is her own, so are her hands, mum, mum, no words against your wife.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Tut, tut, thou art a fool, keep her close from the apothecary, let her taste of no licorice, it will make her long winded: no plums, nor no parsnips, no pears, nor no Popperings, she will dream in her sleep then, let her live upon Hazels, give her nuts for her diet while a tooth is in her head: give her cheese for digestion: it will make her short winded if that will not serve, set fire to the pan and blow her up with Gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife
sp.p: Aye, Aye, mine Host, you are well employed to give a man counsel against his wife, they are apt enough to ill I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Cornu:
sp.p: Mum, mum, my sweet wife, I know the world well enough, I have an ear, but I hear not: an eye, but I see not: what is spoke against thee, I regard not: mum, mum, I know the world well enough.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Aye, and it were more seemly you were at your own house too, your wife cannot go abroad but you must follow, husbands must be fringed to their wives Petticoats, I pray your tarry you, I will go home.

sp.speaker: Cor.
