sp.p: Not so my sweet wife, I am gone, I am vanished, mum, mum, no anger shall stir thee, no words, I know the world well enough.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: It were better by thrice deuce-ace in a week every woman could awe her husband so well as she.

sp.speaker: Gracc.
sp.p: Is it possible, 'sfoot well, I thought it had been but a fable all this while, that Jove should make great Hercules spit on his thumbs, and spin, but now I see, if a man were as great as Caesar, Julius, or Augustus, or both in one, a woman may take him down.
Gossip, faith I will use a little of your counsel, but my husband is so fat, I fear I shall never bring him to it.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Now gentles, you that can prepare a few tears to shed, for now enters a sad scene of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.p:
Man is flesh, and flesh is frail, The strongest man at length must fail, Man is flesh, and flesh is grass, Consuming time as in a glass. Now is up, and now is down, And is not purchased by a Crown. Now seed, and now we are sown, Now we wither, now are mown, Frater noster here doth lie, In paupertate he did die. And now is gone his viam longam, That leads unto his requiem aeternam
But dying needy, poor and bare, Wanting to discharge the Fryer, Unto his grave, he is like to pass, Having neither Dirge nor Mass. So set forward, let him go, Et benedicamus Domino.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: And then to Apollo, holla trees, holla, Tapster a few more clothes to my feet.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: O heavens!

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Gentles, keep your places, fear nothing: in the name of God what art thou?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: My Hearse and winding sheet: what means this? why Gentles I am a living man.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Spirit thou liest, thou deludest us.

sp.speaker: City wife:
sp.p: Conjure him Fryer.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.p:
In nomino Domini, I thee charge, Responde mihi here at large. Cuium pecus whence thou art: Et quam obrem, thou makest us start, In spiritus of the gloomy night? Qui Venis huc us to affright
Per trinitatem I there charge thee, Quid tu vis hic to tell to me.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Why gentles, I am a living man Philantus, what instance shall I give ye? hear me, I have sight, understanding, I know mine hostess, I see that Gentlewoman, I can feel.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Feel this Gentlewoman! 'slid if ye were ten Ghosts, I will not endure it.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Spirit thou deludest us.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Why, what should I say? will ye hear my voice, here is none but ---

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Nay, that is a lie, then it is a living spirit, I will have a bout with him.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: O sir, meddle not with shadows, spirit thou liest, I saw thee dead, so did many more: We know ye wandering dwellers in the dark, Have power to shape you like mortality, To beguile the simple, and deceive their souls, Thou art a Devil.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Sweet Gent, behold I am flesh and blood, here is my flesh feel it.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife
sp.p: By my troth methinks he should be alive, I could find in my heart to feel his flesh.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Try with your Rapier Accutus, if he bleed he lives.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: If I bleed I die, sweet Gentlemen draw no blood.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: How shall we know thou art flesh and blood then?

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: Take heed Accutus he will blast thee.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: What instance shall I give ye? I am Phylantus, he that must needs confess he was drunk in your companies last day, sweet Gentlemen conceive me aright.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p:
Why true, true, that we know, and those syilling bowels,
Death did arrest thee, many saw thee dead, Else needles were these rites of funerals, And since that time till now, no breath was known,
Fly from you: and twenty times the hourglass, Hath turned his upside down: and twenty times The nimble current sand hath left his upper room, To lie beneath, since spark of life appeared, In all which time, my care employed itself, To give the rights of burial: now if you live, Who so glad as I?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Sir, your love hath shown itself abundant, but the cold air is a means to divorce me from your companies: mine host let me crave passage to my chamber.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: Out of my doors knave, thou enterest not my doors, I have no chalk in my house, my posts shall not be guarded with a little sing song, si nihil attuleris ibis Homere foras.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p:
Ha, how now man? seest now any errors? Nay, this is nothing: he hath but shown A pattern in himself, what thou shalt find In others: search through the Globe of earth
If there amongst twenty, two thou doest find Honester than himself I will be buried straight, Now think what shame it is to be vild, And how vild to be drunk: look round, where? Nay look up, behold yon Crystal palace, There sits an ubiquitary Judge, From whom arcana nulla abscondita. That sees all and at pleasure punisheth, Thou canst not scape scot free, how canst thou? Why senseless man, in that, sin will betray His father, brother, nay, him himself: fears not To commit the worst of evils: secure, if Thunder bolts should drop from heaven, dreading Nor heaven nor hell: indeed his best state Is worse than least, prised at highest rate.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: This critique is harsh, unsavoury, and reproofeful, avoid him.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p:
He speaks well, but I like not his dispraising
of drunkenness: it is Physic to me, and it makes me to sleep like a good horse, with my nose in the manger, come sweet heart.
Seignior Philantus I pray ye a word.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: How now, whispering? 'sfoot if they should give our purpose another cross point, where are we then? note, note.

sp.speaker: Hostess,
sp.p: Here take the key, convey yourself into the Chamber, but in any case take heed my husband see you not.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Fear not: gentles, be thanks the guerdon of your love, till time give better ability,

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Ha! nay 'sfoot, I must claw out another device: we must not part so, Graccus prithee keep the scene till I fetch more actors to fill it fuller.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: But prithee let me partake.

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Not till I return, pardon me,
By my troth gossip I am half sick of a conceit

sp.speaker: Cittiy wife.
sp.p: What woman? passion of my heart, tell me your grief?
I shall go to court now, and attired like an old Dairy woman, a Ruff, holland of eight groats, three inches deep of the old cut, and a hat as far out of fashion as a close placket.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Why I hope your husband is able to maintain you better: are there not nights as well as days? does he not sleep some times? has he no pockets about him? cannot you search his breeches? anything you find in his breeches is your own.
But may a woman do that with safety?

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Aye and more, why should she not? why what is his is yours, what is yours, your own:

The best hope I have is, you know my Guest Mistress Gettica, she has pawned her Jewels to me already, and this night I look for her Hood, and her attire, or if the worst chance, I know I can entreat her to wear my
clothes, and let me go in her attire to Court.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Or if all fail, you may hire a good suite at a Jews: or at a brokers, it is a common thing and specially among the common sort.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: To search through my house, I have no Varlets no knaves, no stewed prunes, no she fiery phagies, my Chambers are swept, my sinks are all scoured, the honest shall come in, the knaves shall go by, yet will I master Constable, go search through my house, I care not a sheeps skin.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: We are compelled to do it mine host, a Gentleman is robbed last night, and we are to search every privy corner.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Mine host is true Metal, a man of reputation, a true Holefernes, he loves juice of grapes, and welcome master Constable.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Graccus, how likest thou this?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Excellent, for now must he needs fall into the Constables hands: and if he have any grace, it will appear in his face, when he shall be carried through the street in a white sheet it will be a good penance for his fault.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: Now fortune favour that my husband find him not

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: He will be horn mad, and never able to endure it: why woman if he have but as much man in him as a Maribone, he will take the burthen upon his own neck, and never discover you
Alas here they come, let us away Gossip.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Fortune my foe, why dost, etcetera

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: O fie, that is bitter, prithee go comfort him.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Faith he should be innocent by his garment: Seignior, I grieve for this, but if I can help, look for it.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I thank ye sir.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: We must contaminate our office, pray regard us as little as ye can.

sp.speaker: Accut:
sp.p:
Methinks this should put him quite out of tune: now so, let him go, now to mine Host, there is he, and he,
and he, there is she, and she, I will have about with all: and critiques, honeys sweetest, mixed with gal.

sp.speaker: Host;
sp.p: Go to, there is knaves in my house, I know of no Varlets, I have an eye has his sense, a brain that can reach, I have been called Politician, my wife is my wife, I am her top, I am her head: if mine Host say the word, the Mouse shall be dun.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Not so my sweet Host, mum, mum, no words against your wife, he that means to live quiet, to sleep in clean sheets, a Pillow under his head, his diet dressed cleanly, mum, mum, no words against his wife.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Thou art a fool, thou art a fool, be ruled by mine host, show thyself a brave man of the true seed of Troy; a gallant Agamemnon, thou hast a shrew to thy wife, if she cross thy brave humours, kick thy heel at her huckle bone.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Gentles, most happily encountered, how good hap hath turned two labours into one, I was addressed to both, and at once have met both sure I must entreat that you must not deny.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Say on my sweet bully, mine Host will attend thee, speak roundly to the purpose and welcome my bully.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Marry thus: there are are great revels and shows prepared to beautify the nuptials of Lentulus and Tully, in which the Cittizens have the least share, now would but you and some others that I shall collect, join hands with me in some quaintest, Our show shall deserve grace, and brave the rest.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I have thee brave spirit, thou art of the true seed of Troy, let us be merry and wise, merry hearts live long mine Host, my brave Host with his neighbour Cornutus shall be two of the Maskers, and the Morris shall be danced,

sp.speaker: Cor:
sp.p: Not so mine Host, I dare not do so, it will distemper my wife, my house will be unquiet, mum, mum, I know the world well enough.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Thou shalt go says mine Host, merry hearts live long, welcome bully, mine Host shall make one, so shall my Cornutus, for if I say the word, the mouse shall be dun.

sp.speaker: Porters.
sp.p: Save ye mine Host, here is a parcel of Corn was directed to be delivered at your house.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: What ware my little Atlas, what ware is it?

sp.speaker: 2. Por:
sp.p: I know not, but I am sure it is as heavy as a horse and ---

sp.speaker: 1 Por:
sp.p: I think it is a barrel of oil, for it spurged at my back.
It was oil, for I drew the Tap.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: What Boss, what makest thou here?

sp.speaker: Acc:
sp.p: O chara deum soboles magnum bouis increm entum! Boss art there there?

sp.speaker: Boss:
sp.p: As sure as you are there Seignior.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: Boss, will ye not forsake your Cabin?
O sir, he that has not a tilde house must be glad of a thatched house: may I crave a suite of you seignior?

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: What suite Boss?
What you please, beggars must not choose.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Boss is grown mystical, he is too dark.
I speak hebrew indeed like Adam and Eve, before they fell to spinning: not a rag.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: What, naked Boss?
As ye see, will ye hear my suite seignior?

sp.speaker: Gra:
sp.p: Drunk and his clothes stolen, what thief would do it?

sp.speaker: Boss:
sp.p: Any thief sir, but no true man.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Well Boss, to obtain a suite at my hands, and to do some penance for your fault, you shall here maintain an argument in the defence of drunkenness: mine Host shall hear it I will be your opponent, Acutus moderator: wilt thou do it.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: A mad merry prig, all good spirits, wilt thou do it Boss?

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: I will do it.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Seat ye, here is, my place, now Boss propound.

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: Drunkenness is a virtue.

sp.speaker: Gra:
sp.p: Your proof.

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: Good drink is full of virtue, Now full of good drink is drunk, Ergo, to be drunk is to be virtuous.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: I deny it, good drink is full of vice, Drink takes away the senses, Man that is senseless is vicious, Ergo, good drink is full of vice.
I deny it still, good drink makes good blood, Good blood needs no Barber, Ergo, it is good to drink good drink.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: He holds ye hard Graccus.

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: Here is stronger proof, drunkenness engenders with two of the moral virtues, and six of the liberal sciences.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Let him prove that and I will yield.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: A mad spirit i'faith.

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: A drunkard is valiant and liberal, he will outface Mars, brave Hercules, and fears not the Devil, then for the most part he is liberal, for he will give all the clothes off his back, though he weep like a Widow all the day following: nay, for the sciences, he is a good physician he vomits himself rarely, and will give any man else a vomit that looks on him (if he have not a very good stomach) perfect in Geometry, for he hangs in the air by his own conceit, and feels no ground: and he is all musical, the world turns round with him, every face in the painted cloth shows like a Fairy dancing about him, and every spar in the house a minstrel.

sp.speaker: Grac:
sp.p: Good: forward.

Then he is a good Lawyer, for he is never without a fiery facies, and the least Capias will take his habeas Corpus: besides, another point of a Lawyer, he will rail
and rave against his dearest friends, and make the world think they are enemies, when the next day they will laugh, be fat and drunk together: and a rare Astronomer, for he has stars twinkling in his eyes, in the darkest night, when a wise man discerns none in the firmament, and will take great pains in the practise: for lay him on his back in the open fields overnight, and you shall be sure to find him there in the morning: have I said well, or shall I give you a stronger proof? an honest man will be as good as his word: Seignior Graccus is an honest man, Ergo I must have a new suite.

sp.speaker: Accu:
sp.p: The moderator concludes so, Graccus is overthrown so far as the damage of a suite, so away with him, come, our fire will out, strip us, mine Host and you we expect your companies, we must crave absence awhile, better to furnish our purposes: the time of the day to ye.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Farewell my good bullies, mine Host has said and the mouse is dun.

div2.stage: Enter the dumb shew of the marriage, Lentulus, Tully, and the rest. Enter Hostis in Getticaes apparel, Getic. in hers, & Mistris Dama.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: Come Gossip, by my troth I cannot keep my hood in frame.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: Let me help ye woman.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Sir, we shall be troublesome to ye.

sp.speaker: Gra:
sp.p: O urge not that I pray ye.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I pray ye what show will be here tonight? I have seen the Baboons already, the Cittie of new Niniuie, and Julius Caesar acted by the Mammets.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: O gentlewoman, those are shows for those places they are used in, marry here you must expect some rare device as Diana bathing herself, being discovered or occulated, by Acteon, he was transfigured to a heart, and worried to death with his own dogs.

sp.speaker: Cit. w.
sp.p: That is pretty in good truth, and must Diana be naked?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: O of necessity, if it be that show.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: And Acteon too: that is pretty i'faith.

div2.stage: Enter Caesar, Lent, Tully, Teren, Flauia.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p:
Now gallant Bridegrooms, and your lovely Brides, That have in germinate, in endless league, Your troth plight hearts in your nuptial vows, Tied true love knots, that nothing can dissolve,
Till death that meagre pursuivant of Jove, That Cancels all bonds: we are too cloudy, My spirit a tiptoe nothing I could chid so much, As winged time that gins to free a passage, To his turrent glass, and crops our daylight. That misty night will summon us to rest, Before we feel the burthen of our eyelids. The time is tedious, wants variety, But that I may show what delightful raptures, Combats my soul, to see this union, And with what boundless joy I do embrace it, We here command all prison gates fly ope, Freeing all prisoners, (traitors all except, That poor men's prayers may increase our days, And writers circle ye with wreathes of bays.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: 'sfoot Accutus let us lay hold of this, to free our captive.

sp.speaker: Acu:
sp.p: Content; I will prosecute it.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p:
Dread sovereign, heaven witness with me, With what bended spirit I have attained
This height of happiness: and how unwillingly, Till heavens decree, Terentias love, and your Fair consents, did meet in one, to make Me Lord thereof: nor shall it add one scruple, Of high thought to my lowly mind. Tully is Tully, parentage poor, the best, An Orator, but equal with the least.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: O no doubt Accutus, be the attempt, My peril, his royal promise is past In that behalf: my sovereign, this Gentleman's Request, takes hold upon your gracious promise, For the releasement of a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: My promise is irrevocable, take it: but what is he and the quality of his fault?

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: A gentleman, may it please your grace, his fault suspicion, and most likely innocent.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p:
He hath freedom, and I prithee let him be brought hither Perhaps in his presence we shall win some smiles, For I have noted oft in a simple brain (Only striving to excel itself)
Hath corrupted language that hath turned To pleasant laughter, in judicious ears: Such may this prove, for now methinks Each minute, wanting sport doth seem As long and tedious, as a fever: but who doth know
The true condition of this Accutus?

sp.speaker: Tully:
sp.p: My Liege, of him something my knowledge, Can discover, his spirit is free as air, His temper temperate, if aught is uneven, His spleen ways down lenity: but how Stirred by reproof, and then he is bitter, and like His name, Acute, vice to him is a foul eyesore. And could he stifle it in bitterest words, he would, And who so offends, to him is parallel, He will as soon reprove the Cedar state, As the low shrub.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Nay good Accutus let me not enter the presence:

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: O sir, I assure you your presence will be more acceptable in the presence at this time, than a far richer present: May it please your majesty, this is the man.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Let him stand forward.

sp.speaker: Cit. w.
sp.p: Alas we shall see nothing, would I were near now he stands forwards.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife.
sp.p: What qualities hath he Accutus?

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Few good ones (may it please you) he handles a comb well, a brush better, and will drink down a Dutchman, and has good skill in prick song.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: Aye, I will be sworn, he had when he was my Guest,

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Please it your Majesty to command him?

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: O, we can no otherwise so well be pleased.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I beseech your Majesty, I cannot sing.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Nay, your denial will breed but greater expectation of your skill.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, please it your grace to hear? now he begins.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: My love can sing no other song, but still complains I did her, etcetera I beseech your Majesty to let me go.

sp.speaker: Caes:
sp.p: With all our heart, Acutus give him liberty.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Go, and for voice sake ye shall sing Ballads in the suburbs, and if ever hereafter ye chance to purchase a suite by what your friends shall leave ye, or the credit of your friend, be not drunk again, and give him hard words for his labour.

sp.speaker: Caes:
sp.p: What, is it effected Graccus?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I have wrought the fool, Scilicet comes alone, and his Lady keeps the women company.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: Tush, we will have a room scantily furnished with lights that shall further it.

sp.speaker: Caes:
sp.p: What sound is that?

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Aye, would ye so fain enter? I will further it: please it your Majesty to accept what is not worth acceptance? here are a company to Gratulate these nuptials, have prepared a show, I fear not worth the sight, if you shall deem to give them the beholding of it.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Else should we wrong their kindness much: Accutus, be it your care to give them kindest welcome, we cannot recompense their loves without much beholdings.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Now for the cunning vizarding of them, and it is done,

sp.speaker: Hostess:
sp.p: Now we shall behold the shows.

sp.speaker: Get
sp.p: Acteon and his Dogs I pray Jupiter.

div2.stage: Enter the marke and the Song,

sp.p: Chant birds in every bush The Blackbird and the Thrush The chirping Nightingale. The Mavis and Wagtail, The Linnet and the Lark O how they begin, hark, hark!

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: 'slid there is one bird I do not like her voice.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: By my troth methought one should be my husband, I could even discern his voice thorough his vizard.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: And truly by his head one should be mine.

sp.speaker: Get:
sp.p: And surely by his ears one should be my sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Accutus, you have deserved much of our love, But might we not break the law of sport so far, As to know to whom our thanks is due, By seeing them unmasked, and the reason of their habits?

sp.speaker: Acut:
sp.p: Most willingly my Sovereign, I will cause their return.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: O excellent! now we shall see them unmasked.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: In troth I had good hope the foremost had been Acteon when I saw his horns.

sp.speaker: Cit. wif.
sp.p: Sure the middle most was my husband, see if he have not a wen in his forehead.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: God bless thee noble Caesar, and all these brave bridegrooms with their fine little dy-doppers, that look before they sleep to throw away their maiden heads: I am host of the Hobby, Cornut is my neighbour, but we will pull off his bo-peeper, thou wilt know me by my nose, I am a mad merry grig, come to make thy grace laugh, sir Scillicet my guest, all true canaries that love juice of grapes, god bless thy Majesty.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: How now mine Host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I spy a jest, ha ha, Cornutus, Cornutus.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Nay mine host, here is a moat in your eye too.

sp.speaker: Scil:
sp.p: 'slid I hope they have not served me so: by the torrid you are an ass, a flat Ass, but the best is I know who did it, it was either you or somebody else, for I was in no company of mankind else, by gad I remember it as well as if it were done now.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: Thou shalt answer it to my liege, I will not be so misused, ye have a wrong element, there is fire in my face, we will mount and ascend. I am misused the mad comrades have played the knaves, justice my brave Caesar.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p:
I will answer ye mine Host: pardon great Caesar, The intent was merriment, the reason this: A true brow bends, to see good things amiss, Men turned to beasts, and such are you mine Host See you this, this represents a beast, That cannot see his shame, and such are you mine Host. I will show you else, you are a Goat, look here! Now come you, this is yours, you know it, do you not? How old are you? are you not a Goat now? Shall I teach thee how to use a wife and keep her?
In the rank of goodness link her to thy soul, Divide not indiuidium, be her and she thee, Keep her from the Serpent, let her not Gad To every Gossips congregation, For there is blushing modesty laid out, And a free rein to sensual turpitude, Given out at length and libidinous acts, Free chat, each giving counsel and censure.
Capream maritum facere, such art thou Goat, Be not so secure: and you my grand Cornutus, Thou Ram, thou seest thy shame a penthouse To thy eyebrows: dost not glory in it, dost? Thou wilt lie in a Truckle bed, at thy wives bed feet, And let her go a Gossiping while thou sweepest the kitchen, Look, she shall witnesses against thee.

sp.speaker: Corn:
sp.p: My wife there? I must be gone then.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: O fie, betray not thyself so grossly.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I Pray ye pardon me.

sp.speaker: Accut:
sp.p: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Cor:
sp.p: Aye sir, but afterwards may come after claps, I know the world well enough.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Mischief of the Devil, be man not all beast, do not lie, --- both sheets do not.

sp.speaker: Cit. w:
sp.p: I warrant this fellow has as many eyes as a Lamprey, he could never see so far into the world else.

sp.speaker: Accu.
sp.p: And thou pure ass, mere ass, thy ears become thee well i'faith

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: I think you meant to make a Musician of me, you furnish me with a good ear.

sp.speaker: Accut.
sp.p: Thou deservedest it, thou wilt make thyself a Cuckold be it but for company sake, thou hast long ears, and thinkest them horns, thy conceits cuckolds thee, thou art jealous if thou seest thy wives --- With another man's palm. And fool, thy state in that sense is the best: thou art clasped with simplicity, (a great badge of honesty) for she poor fool has pawned her clothes to redeem thy unthriftiness: be Jealous no more, unless thou wilt wear thine ears still, for all shall well and you shall have your puppy again.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Shall I? by my troth I shall be beholding to you then.

sp.speaker: Acu:
sp.p:
Now to ye all, be firmaments to stars, Be stars to Firmaments, and as you are Splendent, so be fixed, not wandering, nor Irregular, both keeping course together, Shine not in pride, and gorgeous attire, When clouds do fail, the pole where thou art fixed. Obey, cherish, honour, be kind enough, But let them wear no changeable stuff, Keep them, as shall become your state,
Comely, and to creep ere they go. Let them partake your joys, and weep with you, Curl not the snarls that dwell upon these brows,
In all things be you kind of all enough, But let them wear no changeable stuff.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: Fore God a mad spirit.
Will ye believe, what such a biscuit brained fellow as this says? he has a mouth like a double cannon, the report will be heard all over the town.

sp.speaker: Cittie wife:
sp.p: I warrant he ran mad for love, because no good face could endure the sight of him, and ever since he rails against women like a whot shot.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Nay, nay, we must have all friends. Jarring discords are no marriage music, Throw not Hymen in a cuck-stool, dimple Your furrowed brows, since all but mirth was meant, Let us not then conclude in discontent. Say, shall we all in friendly strain Measure our paces to bedward?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Will Terentia follow?

sp.speaker: Teren:
sp.p: If Tully be her Leader.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: Good bloods, good spirits, let me answer for all, none speak but mine Host, he has his pols and his aedypols, his times and his tricks, his quirks and his quilts, and his demise and dimensions, God bless thee Noble Caesar, and all these brave spirits, I am Host of the Hobby, Cornutus is my neighbour: Graccus a mad spirit, Accutus is my friend, Sir Scillicet is my guest, all mad comrades of the true seed of troy, that love juice of Grapes: we are all true friends, merry hearts live long, let the Pipers strike up I will dance my cinquepace, cut a loft my brave capers, whirl about my toe, do my tricks above ground, I will kiss my sweet hostess, make a courtesy to thy grace, God bless thy Majesty, and the Mouse shall be dun.

sp.speaker: Cor:
sp.p: Come wife, will you dance?

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: I will not dance I, must you come to the Court to have horns set on your head? I could have done that at home.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: Aye, Aye, be ruled at this time, what, for one merry day we will find a whole moon at midsummer.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Gentles, we thank ye all, the night hath spent his youth, and drowsy Morpheus bids us battle, We will defy him still, we will keep him out While we have power to do it, sound your loudest noise, Set forward to our chamber.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Advance your light.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Good rest to all.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: God give your grace Goodnight.
